title: "Policy Implications"
description: "Why global security coordination is a public good — and why we're free-riding"
---

## The Collective Action Problem

The findings reveal an uncomfortable truth: peace near strategic waterways is currently a **byproduct of self-interest**, not coordinated policy.

When trade is booming, major powers protect choke points because it serves their economic interests. But this protection is unreliable — it depends on trade volumes and the self-interest calculus of a few powerful nations.

:::{.callout-warning}
## The Free-Rider Problem
As economist Mancur Olson showed in his classic 1965 work, public goods — benefits everyone shares but nobody individually pays for — tend to be underprovided. Global maritime security is a textbook case: every nation benefits from open shipping lanes, but intervention is costly and risky.
:::

## What This Means for Policy

The research points toward three implications:

**1. Supranational coordination matters.** Relying on major powers' self-interest is insufficient. Organizations like the United Nations should play a larger role in guaranteeing safe maritime passage — especially during periods of low trade.

**2. Trade agreements are security agreements.** The data shows that trade openness itself reduces conflict in strategic locations. Trade policy and security policy are more intertwined than commonly assumed.

**3. Deglobalization carries security risks.** If world trade openness declines — as some current trends suggest — the protective effect weakens, and strategic locations become more contested again.

## World Trade Openness Over Time

```{ojs}
//| echo: false

tradeData = FileAttachment("data/trade_openness.json").json()
```

```{ojs}
//| echo: false

{
  const width = 700;
  const height = 350;
  const margin = {top: 30, right: 30, bottom: 50, left: 60};

  const crossover = 0.534;

  const x = d3.scaleLinear()
    .domain(d3.extent(tradeData, d => d.year))
    .range([margin.left, width - margin.right]);

  const yExtent = d3.extent(tradeData, d => d.trade_openness);
  const y = d3.scaleLinear()
    .domain([Math.min(yExtent[0], 0.34), Math.max(yExtent[1], 0.62)])
    .range([height - margin.bottom, margin.top]);

  const svg = d3.create("svg")
    .attr("viewBox", [0, 0, width, height])
    .attr("width", width)
    .attr("height", height)
    .style("max-width", "100%")
    .style("font-family", "'Source Sans 3', sans-serif");

  // Danger zone (below crossover)
  svg.append("rect")
    .attr("x", margin.left).attr("y", y(crossover))
    .attr("width", width - margin.left - margin.right)
    .attr("height", y(0.34) - y(crossover))
    .attr("fill", "#ffebee").attr("opacity", 0.5);

  // Safe zone (above crossover)
  svg.append("rect")
    .attr("x", margin.left).attr("y", y(0.62))
    .attr("width", width - margin.left - margin.right)
    .attr("height", y(crossover) - y(0.62))
    .attr("fill", "#e8f5e9").attr("opacity", 0.5);

  // Zone labels
  svg.append("text")
    .attr("x", width - margin.right - 5).attr("y", y(crossover) + 15)
    .attr("text-anchor", "end").attr("fill", "#c62828")
    .attr("font-size", "10px").attr("font-weight", "600")
    .text("CONFLICT ZONE");

  svg.append("text")
    .attr("x", width - margin.right - 5).attr("y", y(crossover) - 6)
    .attr("text-anchor", "end").attr("fill", "#2e7d32")
    .attr("font-size", "10px").attr("font-weight", "600")
    .text("PEACE ZONE");

  // Crossover line
  svg.append("line")
    .attr("x1", margin.left).attr("x2", width - margin.right)
    .attr("y1", y(crossover)).attr("y2", y(crossover))
    .attr("stroke", "#7e57c2").attr("stroke-dasharray", "6,3").attr("stroke-width", 1.5);

  svg.append("text")
    .attr("x", margin.left + 5).attr("y", y(crossover) - 6)
    .attr("fill", "#7e57c2").attr("font-size", "10px")
    .text(`Tipping point: ${crossover}`);

  // Trade openness line
  const line = d3.line()
    .x(d => x(d.year))
    .y(d => y(d.trade_openness))
    .curve(d3.curveMonotoneX);

  svg.append("path")
    .datum(tradeData)
    .attr("d", line)
    .attr("fill", "none")
    .attr("stroke", "#1a237e")
    .attr("stroke-width", 2.5);

  // Data points
  svg.append("g")
    .selectAll("circle")
    .data(tradeData)
    .join("circle")
    .attr("cx", d => x(d.year))
    .attr("cy", d => y(d.trade_openness))
    .attr("r", 3)
    .attr("fill", d => d.trade_openness >= crossover ? "#43a047" : "#e53935");

  // Annotations for key events
  const annotations = [
    {year: 1991, label: "End of Cold War", dy: -15},
    {year: 2001, label: "China joins WTO", dy: 20},
    {year: 2008, label: "Financial crisis", dy: -15},
  ];

  for (const a of annotations) {
    const datum = tradeData.find(d => d.year === a.year);
    if (datum) {
      svg.append("line")
        .attr("x1", x(a.year)).attr("x2", x(a.year))
        .attr("y1", y(datum.trade_openness) + (a.dy > 0 ? 6 : -6))
        .attr("y2", y(datum.trade_openness) + a.dy)
        .attr("stroke", "#999").attr("stroke-width", 1);

      svg.append("text")
        .attr("x", x(a.year)).attr("y", y(datum.trade_openness) + a.dy + (a.dy > 0 ? 12 : -4))
        .attr("text-anchor", "middle").attr("fill", "#666")
        .attr("font-size", "9px").attr("font-weight", "600")
        .text(a.label);
    }
  }

  // Axes
  svg.append("g")
    .attr("transform", `translate(0,${height - margin.bottom})`)
    .call(d3.axisBottom(x).ticks(8).tickFormat(d3.format("d")))
    .call(g => g.append("text")
      .attr("x", width / 2).attr("y", 40)
      .attr("fill", "#555").attr("text-anchor", "middle")
      .attr("font-size", "13px")
      .text("Year"));

  svg.append("g")
    .attr("transform", `translate(${margin.left},0)`)
    .call(d3.axisLeft(y).ticks(6).tickFormat(d3.format(".2f")))
    .call(g => g.append("text")
      .attr("transform", "rotate(-90)")
      .attr("x", -height / 2).attr("y", -45)
      .attr("fill", "#555").attr("text-anchor", "middle")
      .attr("font-size", "13px")
      .text("World Trade Openness (share of GDP)"));

  return svg.node();
}
```

:::{.callout-tip}
## Reading the chart
Each dot represents one year of global trade openness. When trade is **above the tipping point** (0.534), proximity to choke points reduces conflict. When trade drops **below**, the protective effect vanishes. Notice how the 2008 financial crisis pushed trade back toward the danger zone.
:::
